qas.question: Who discussed rumors of a mysterious "MacIntosh" project in 1983?
How much did the television commercial "1984" cost?
What did the television commercial "1984" introduce?
What did Regis McKenna call the "1984" ad that was aired during the Super Bowl?
Who discussed rumors of a mysterious "MacIntosh" project in 1938?
How much did the television commercial "1948" cost?
What did the television commercial "1948" introduce?
What did Regis McKenna call the "1948" ad that was aired during the Super Bowl?

context: After the Lisa's announcement, <a0_0><b5_0>John Dvorak<b5_0/><a0_0/> discussed rumors of a mysterious "MacIntosh" project at Apple in February 1983. The company announced the <a3_0><b8_0>Macintosh 128K<b8_0/><a3_0/>—manufactured at an <a1_0><b6_0>Apple factory in Fremont, California<b6_0/><a1_0/>—in October 1983, followed by an 18-page brochure included with various magazines in December. The Macintosh was introduced by a <a2_0><b7_0>US$1.5 million<b7_0/><a2_0/> Ridley Scott television commercial, "1984". It most notably aired during the third quarter of Super Bowl XVIII on January 22, 1984, and is now considered a "watershed event" and a "masterpiece." Regis McKenna called the ad <a4_0><b9_0>"more successful than the Mac itself."<b9_0/><a4_0/> "1984" used an unnamed heroine to represent the coming of the Macintosh (indicated by a Picasso-style picture of the computer on her white tank top) as a means of saving humanity from the "conformity" of IBM's attempts to dominate the computer industry. The ad alludes to George Orwell's novel, Nineteen Eighty-Four, which described a dystopian future ruled by a televised "Big Brother."
